linkTarget.anchoringText: The stylolite layers are tight but not zero-permeable and the communications between sub-reservoirs are observed by the data obtained from logs and dynamic testing throughout the whole field. As shown in Fig. 1, this reservoir is sectorized into five areas based on geological similarity – North East, Heterogeneous, Homogeneous, Near West and West area. The North East area is fractured and faulted, having high heterogeneity and uncertainty of geology. The Near West area is relatively tight and homogeneous. The West area is tighter and undeveloped. The Homogeneous area is relatively permeable and homogeneous. The Heterogeneous area is permeable and heterogeneous with high-perm streaks (HKS) in the upper layers (Layer A to C). HKS have several hundred mD permeability compared with 5-20 mD matrix (non-HKS) permeability. Fig. 2 shows the HKS distribution in the reservoir with boundaries of Heterogeneous and Homogeneous area. We previously conducted a multi-year screening study to select the primary target areas for miscible EOR (Willingham et. al. 2016). As a result of the prior study, the Heterogeneous and Homogeneous areas were identified as the main target areas for miscible EOR based on potential recoverable oil volume and attractiveness for miscible EOR implementation.

The stylolite layers are tight but not zero-permeable and the communications between sub-reservoirs are observed by the data obtained from logs and dynamic testing throughout the whole field. As shown in Fig. 1, this reservoir is sectorized into five areas based on geological similarity – North East, Heterogeneous, Homogeneous, Near West and West area. The North East area is fractured and faulted, having high heterogeneity and uncertainty of geology. The Near West area is relatively tight and homogeneous. The West area is tighter and undeveloped. The Homogeneous area is relatively permeable and homogeneous. The Heterogeneous area is permeable and heterogeneous with high-perm streaks (HKS) in the upper layers (Layer A to C). HKS have several hundred mD permeability compared with 5-20 mD matrix (non-HKS) permeability. Fig. 2 shows the HKS distribution in the reservoir with boundaries of Heterogeneous and Homogeneous area. We previously conducted a multi-year screening study to select the primary target areas for miscible EOR (Willingham et. al. 2016). As a result of the prior study, the Heterogeneous and Homogeneous areas were identified as the main target areas for miscible EOR based on potential recoverable oil volume and attractiveness for miscible EOR implementation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: HKS Distribution Map with EOR Target Area Boundaries

formatted-caption.caption-text: HKS Distribution Map with EOR Target Area Boundaries

linkTarget.anchoringText: The injector had a dual completion with the short string perforated across upper layers (Layer A and B) and the long string completed in lower layers (Layer E) with 3000 ft horizontal length as shown in Fig. 3. Before gas injection was initiated in the pilot, a water injector located 150 m away from the pilot gas injector was converted to an observer when the pilot gas injector was drilled. During the gas injection pilot, water was injected from the short string and lean HC gas was injected from the long string. This injection scheme was called as SWAG (Simultaneous Water And Gas). The purpose of this unique injection scheme was to inject water into the upper layers to prevent or minimize gas override due to gravity and improve the vertical sweep efficiency of gas injection.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Pilot Well Pattern and SWAG Injector Schematic Figure 12 Well Location Maps

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pilot Well Pattern and SWAG Injector Schematic Figure 12 Well Location Maps

linkTarget.anchoringText: For the history match simulation, a sector model was built for the SWAG pilot area. The gas breakthrough timing at the NE producer in the simulation model matched with the observation from the actual SWAG pilot. Fig. 4 shows the gas saturation map of the history matched simulation at the timing of gas breakthrough to NE producer. Simulation results suggest that the injected gas overrides to the upper layers and hence preferentially sweeps the upper layers due to the lower density of lean gas and HKS in upper layers (i.e. the water injection from short string could not prevent the gas override).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Gas Saturation Map of History Matched Simulation

formatted-caption.caption-text: Gas Saturation Map of History Matched Simulation

linkTarget.anchoringText: A simulation study for the assessment of miscible WAG injection has been conducted as a part of extensive EOR study initiated in 2000s. The sector model shown in Fig. 5 was used for the assessment of WAG injection. This model was cut from the history matched full field simulation model and is considered a representative of the maturity and geology in the Heterogeneous geologic area. Through the sensitivity and optimization studies, several WAG injection schemes were evaluated to optimize oil recovery and minimize the gas usage. The optimized WAG injection scheme, a "Tapered" WAG, modifies the duration of gas injection over time with longer gas injection cycles initially which are progressively reduced with subsequent WAG cycles as illustrated in Table 2 and Fig. 6. In addition, line drive injection with 500 m well spacing was identified as an optimal well configuration for the miscible WAG (Kohata et al. 2017).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Sector Model for Miscible WAG Evaluation

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sector Model for Miscible WAG Evaluation

linkTarget.anchoringText: Through the sensitivity and optimization studies, several WAG injection schemes were evaluated to optimize oil recovery and minimize the gas usage. The optimized WAG injection scheme, a "Tapered" WAG, modifies the duration of gas injection over time with longer gas injection cycles initially which are progressively reduced with subsequent WAG cycles as illustrated in Table 2 and Fig. 6. In addition, line drive injection with 500 m well spacing was identified as an optimal well configuration for the miscible WAG (Kohata et al. 2017).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Injection Rate Profile for "Constant" WAG \& "Tapered WAG"
Red: Gas Blue: Water Green: Oil

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 7 shows the prediction of the incremental oil recovery over water injection (base field development plan) by miscible Tapered WAG. The results indicate a 11% incremental oil recovery over water injection at 0.8 Hydrocarbon Pore Volume Injected (HCPVI) of water and gas injection.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Incremental Oil Recovery by Miscible Tapered WAG Injection

formatted-caption.caption-text: Incremental Oil Recovery by Miscible Tapered WAG Injection

linkTarget.anchoringText: The SWAG pilot area (Area 1) was located in between the Homogeneous and Heterogeneous geological regions and the area of the sector model for miscible WAG assessment (Area 2) was located in the Heterogeneous geological region as shown in Fig. 8.Table 3 summarizes the geological properties of Area 1 and Area 2. In order to investigate the impact of the geological difference, a simulation case of Area 2 with same pilot well configuration (well spacing, placement and completion layers) as well as pilot well configurations was generated as shown in Fig. 9 and was compared with the history matched SWAG pilot model of Area 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Location of Area 1 and Area 2 on the HKS Distribution Map

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location of Area 1 and Area 2 on the HKS Distribution Map

linkTarget.anchoringText: The SWAG pilot area (Area 1) was located in between the Homogeneous and Heterogeneous geological regions and the area of the sector model for miscible WAG assessment (Area 2) was located in the Heterogeneous geological region as shown in Fig. 8.Table 3 summarizes the geological properties of Area 1 and Area 2. In order to investigate the impact of the geological difference, a simulation case of Area 2 with same pilot well configuration (well spacing, placement and completion layers) as well as pilot well configurations was generated as shown in Fig. 9 and was compared with the history matched SWAG pilot model of Area 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Well Locations of SWAG Pilot Pattern

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well Locations of SWAG Pilot Pattern

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 10 shows the gas saturation at the time of gas breakthrough to the NE producer. In both cases, the injected gas advanced to only the Eastern side (direction to NE and SE producers) because water was injected from the short string at the heel of the injector and hence prevented gas expansion towards the Western side. The Eastern part of Area 1 is mainly in the Heterogeneous geologic area which is in agreement with Area 2. Fig. 11 shows the GOR increase from the solution GOR of NE producer with HCPVI of the NE area (highlighted in Fig. 10).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Gas Saturation at Gas Breakthrough to Producer NE

formatted-caption.caption-text: Gas Saturation at Gas Breakthrough to Producer NE

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 10 shows the gas saturation at the time of gas breakthrough to the NE producer. In both cases, the injected gas advanced to only the Eastern side (direction to NE and SE producers) because water was injected from the short string at the heel of the injector and hence prevented gas expansion towards the Western side. The Eastern part of Area 1 is mainly in the Heterogeneous geologic area which is in agreement with Area 2. Fig. 11 shows the GOR increase from the solution GOR of NE producer with HCPVI of the NE area (highlighted in Fig. 10).

In order to investigate the sensitivity of the WAG injection scheme, pattern configuration, well spacing and injection fluid, several simulation models having different well locations and spacing were generated. All simulation models are compositional and are based on the Area 2 model. Fig. 12 and Fig. 13 show the well locations of each WAG design and the simulation results, respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Well Location Maps, 5-spot Pattern 1km Spacing, Line Drive 1km Spacing, Line Drive 500m Spacing

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well Location Maps, 5-spot Pattern 1km Spacing, Line Drive 1km Spacing, Line Drive 500m Spacing

linkTarget.anchoringText: In order to investigate the sensitivity of the WAG injection scheme, pattern configuration, well spacing and injection fluid, several simulation models having different well locations and spacing were generated. All simulation models are compositional and are based on the Area 2 model. Fig. 12 and Fig. 13 show the well locations of each WAG design and the simulation results, respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Sensitivity Simulation Results (a) WAG Injection Scheme, (b) Pattern Configuration, (c) Well Spacing, (d) Injection Fluid

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sensitivity Simulation Results (a) WAG Injection Scheme, (b) Pattern Configuration, (c) Well Spacing, (d) Injection Fluid

linkTarget.anchoringText: The impact of the well configuration difference was assessed by comparing the 5-spot pattern Tapered WAG injection case and the line drive Tapered WAG injection case using the Area 2 model. Well location of each case is shown in Fig. 12. As a result, the line drive injection case showed higher recovery relative to the 5-spot pattern injection case as shown in Fig. 13-(b). As shown in Fig. 14, the line drive injection with long laterals (3 km horizontal length) case results in a significantly improved volumetric sweep efficiency relative to the 5-spot configuration.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Gas Saturation Map after 30 Years WAG Injection

formatted-caption.caption-text: Gas Saturation Map after 30 Years WAG Injection

linkTarget.anchoringText: The impact of well spacing was investigated; well locations for 1 km spacing and 500 m spacing are shown in Fig. 12. As a result, the 500 m well spacing showed higher recovery compared to the 1 km spacing as shown in Fig. 13-(c). The cross-sections of the gas saturation in Fig. 15 indicates gas overrides in both cases; however, the 500 m spacing case has a significantly improved volumetric sweep efficiency compared to the 1km spacing case.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Gas Saturation Map after 30 Years WAG Injection

formatted-caption.caption-text: Gas Saturation Map after 30 Years WAG Injection

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 16 summarizes the incremental recovery for all simulation cases. The lowest recovery case was the 1 km spacing 5-spot pattern SWAG injection with immiscible lean HC gas which was the settings for SWAG pilot. On the other hand, the highest recovery case was the 500 m spacing line drive Tapered WAG injection with rich HC gas which are the settings for the optimum development scheme in the miscible HC WAG study.
